summary: This is a government memorandum of law filed in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) opposing the defense's proposed expert testimony of Dr. Park Dietz and Dr. Elizabeth Loftus. The government argues that many of the experts' opinions are irrelevant, unreliable, within the common knowledge of the jury, invade the province of the jury, or are prejudicial. It seeks to preclude specific opinions while allowing a limited response from Dr. Dietz to the government's own expert, Dr. Lisa Rocchio.

keyFacts: The government is moving to preclude large portions of the proposed expert testimony from defense experts Dr. Park Dietz and Dr. Elizabeth Loftus in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

The government argues Dr. Dietz's opinions on topics like 'hindsight bias,' the 'Halo effect,' and 'pathways to false allegations' are irrelevant, unreliable, within the jury's common knowledge, or an invitation to jury nullification.

The government argues Dr. Loftus's opinions on memory fading, contamination, and false memory formation are either commonsense, unreliable as applied to this case, or invade the jury's role in assessing witness credibility.
The government agrees Dr. Dietz may offer a limited opinion responding to Dr. Rocchio about the difficulty of assessing whether grooming occurred.
The document reveals the defense's strategy includes using experts to suggest witness memories may be false or contaminated and to argue Maxwell was influenced by Epstein's 'Halo effect.'
